AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: Corylus americana or the American Filbert is also known as the American Hazel. It is one of three species of Corylus that occur in North America, and one of two that is native to Minnesota. Corylus is the classical Latin name for hazel, possibly derived from the Greek korylos or corys, a helmet, in reference to the husk that surrounds the nut. American Filbert is a relatively large shrub with numerous erect stems and is important in Minnesotan forest ecology because of its abundance. In fact, it is considered a close second to beaked hazel (C. cornuta) as the most abundant understory shrub in Minnesota. The shrub provides structure and function of the forest understory and influences succession of canopy trees.
Numerous upright stems, 3 cm dbh. First year branchlets brown to reddish brown or grayish with non-glandular hairs. Bark thin, gray to gray-brown, smooth or somewhat rough.

Monoecious, male in catkins 1 1/2 to 3" long, yellowish brown, showing in early spring. Female flowers inconspicuous, look like leaf buds with only the stigma and style barely protruding out of the bud. Color is a rich red.
Nut, 1/2" long with a hard, bony shell. Maturing Sept-Oct.
Alternate, simple, 2 1/2-6" long, broad-ovate to broad-elliptic. Base heart-shaped or rounded. Margins irregularly double-serrate.
Large shrub with numerous erect stems. Distinguished from the beaked hazel (C. cornuta) by the short, broad fring at the end of the nut's husk.

ThemeEntityData.Description: Corylus americana or the American Filbert is also known as the American Hazel. It is one of three species of Corylus that occur in North America, and one of two that is native to Minnesota. Corylus is the classical Latin name for hazel, possibly derived from the Greek korylos or corys, a helmet, in reference to the husk that surrounds the nut. American Filbert is a relatively large shrub with numerous erect stems and is important in Minnesotan forest ecology because of its abundance. In fact, it is considered a close second to beaked hazel (C. cornuta) as the most abundant understory shrub in Minnesota. The shrub provides structure and function of the forest understory and influences succession of canopy trees.
